creditline: Gift of Edith and Norman Garmezy
description: dark image of silhouette of hunter with gun and dog; sunrise; row of tall, thin trees at right; slightly lighter border with shadowy rabbits and frog; printed in green
inscription:
Inscription and Stamp

LRC, backwards in the image: [illegible] | On back, in pencil: APGJ624  (and)  9211
markings: LLC on back, stamped in black: EFA | ULC on back, stamped in black: 123
medium: Transfer lithograph with scraping, printed in green ink
provenance: Provenance: Edith and Norman Garmezy, Edina, MN; C. & J. Goodfriend, New York
text: A prolific etcher, Félix Buhot made only seven lithographs over a short period in 1892.  It is surprising that with so little exposure to the medium he decided to show the irregular shape of the lithographic stone.  This creative decision adds to the charm of The Little Hunter, as does the choice of green ink.  Like many of his etchings, Buhot fills the margins of his print with remarques, or extra drawings that are somewhat related to the central image.  Here we see rabbits, the hunter's quarry, as well as a lone frog in the lower right hand corner.
title: The Little Hunter
